Award.AwardTitle: LSU NOYCE TIGERS: Teaching Investigating Guiding Engaging Researching Serving

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Louisiana State University is providing 24 scholarships over four years to juniors and seniors preparing to become science and math teachers in the GEAUX Teach program. In addition, summer research internships are available for freshmen and sophomores to provide teacher candidates with authentic hands on mathematics and science research experiences. These experiences are designed to enable mathematics and science teachers to accurately relay to secondary school students not only the facts and skills of the school subject, but also something of the actual culture of research in the discipline. Thus STEM students may be attracted to the GEAUX Teach program not only because it leads to a teaching credential, but also because it supports their summer internship in a laboratory setting assisting with ongoing research projects under the guidance of university researchers. Although authentic research experience is necessary for the fully capable mathematics and science teacher, it may not be sufficient to ensure teachers can translate that experience into curriculum innovation. To address this, the internship experience is designed to involve summer scholars, as a cohort, with teacher mentors - former graduates of the GEAUX Teach who were previous recipients of Noyce Scholarships whose teaching practices embody the ideals of disciplinary fidelity. By reinvesting in its own graduates, the GEAUX Teach program is building a recursive community of teaching excellence in the surrounding school districts. The project is conducting an assessment of the success of the graduates using a value-added analysis of teacher effectiveness. The evaluation design links the GEAUX Teach program with the statewide data base of longitudinal data within a complex three layer hierarchical model and uses prior achievement, attendance, and demographic variables at the student, classroom, and school levels to estimate teacher preparation effects. This provides a systematic, longitudinal evaluation of NOYCE Scholarship awardees, addressing the impact of the program on teacher retention, attrition, and service in high-need schools/districts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has provided needed support to the GeauxTeach mathematics and science undergraduate teacher education program at Louisiana State University. The program provides an undergraduate degree in mathematics or a science, as well as middle/secondary school Louisiana teacher certification in the subject area. The original grant, along with a supplementary grant, has supported the program through achievement of the following outcomes:

  • Assisted with recruitment by providing twenty four (24) $10,000 and seven (7) $5,000 merit and needs-based scholarships for students during their junior and/or senior year in the program willing to commit to teaching for 2 years in a high needs school district for each one year of support;
  • Bolstered program effectiveness by providing $5,000 in support costs for fifty-one (51) students to engage in summer research internships with a mathematician or scientist and to attend workshops designed to help future teachers incorporate authentic mathematics and science practices into the middle/secondary school curriculum;
  • Provided for development of a special education handbook and a training video to be incorporated into the teacher education program (see program report attachments);
  • Rigorous evaluation of grant outcomes through quantitative and qualitative research components has contributed to our overall monitoring and evaluation of the GeauxTeach program, providing key data on the following critical variables:

-- Graduates’ demographic characteristics

-- Graduates’ professional placement (& at high-needs schools / % working with at-risk student body)

-- Graduates’ retention in teaching

-- Noyce Graduates’ value-added model scores in comparison with GeauxTeach graduates who did not receive Noyce scholarships, and with a comparison group of other mathematics and science teachers in Louisiana (records obtained from the Louisiana Department of Education)
